[](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesExpansion.png "Enlarge")

The area ceded to the United States by Great Britain in 1783 (light brown) is
usually recognized as the Eastern United States. Louisiana and Florida
acquisitions were recognized as the Western and Southern frontiers in the
early days of the Republic. Although east of the
[Rockies](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"), Texas is considered a
Western state.

![File:Aurora Borealis and eastern United States at
Night.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Aurora_Borealis_and_eastern_United_States_at_Night.ogv/300px
--Aurora_Borealis_and_eastern_United_States_at_Night.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/73/Aurora_Borealis_and_eastern_United_States_at_Night.ogv
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Aurora_Borealis_and_eastern_United_States_at_Night.ogv
"Enlarge")

This video was taken by the crew of [Expedition 29](/wiki/Expedition_29
"Expedition 29") on board the [ISS](/wiki/International_Space_Station
"International Space Station"). The pass goes over the eastern United States.

The **Eastern United States** , commonly referred to as the **American East**
or simply **the East** , is a region roughly coinciding with the boundaries of
the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") established in the
[1783 Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\) "Treaty of Paris
\(1783\)"), which bounded the new country to the west along the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). It is geographically
diverse, spanning the [Northeast](/wiki/Northeastern_United_States
"Northeastern United States") and [Southeast](/wiki/Southeastern_United_States
"Southeastern United States") as well as the eastern part of the [Central
United States](/wiki/Central_United_States "Central United States").

In 2011 the 26 states east of the Mississippi (in addition to [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") but not including the small
portions of [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") and
[Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") east of the river) had an estimated
population of 179,948,346 or 58.28% of the total [U.S.
population](/wiki/U.S._population "U.S. population") of 308,745,358 (excluding
[Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico")).

## Southern United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eastern_United_States&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Southern United States")]

Main article: [Southern United States](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern
United States")

The Southern United States constitutes a large region in the south-eastern and
south-central United States, usually enumerated as the following:
[Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"), [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee
"Tennessee"), [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), [West
Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia"), [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland
"Maryland"),[_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:Eastern_United_States#Dubious "Talk:Eastern United
States")_] [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"), [South
Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"),
[Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_\(U.S._state\) "Georgia \(U.S. state\)"),
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida"), [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama "Alabama"),
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi"), [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas
"Arkansas"), and [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"); all of these are
also considered to number among the Eastern United States.

Its unique cultural and historic heritage includes the following aspects:

  * [Native Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the United States")
  * early European settlements of English, Scots-Irish, Scottish and German heritage
  * importation of hundreds of thousands of [enslaved](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States") Africans
  * growth of a large proportion of [African Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") in the population
  * reliance on slave labor
  * legacy of the [Confederacy](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of America") after the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War").

These led to "the South" developing distinctive customs, literature, musical
styles, and varied cuisines, that have profoundly shaped traditional American
culture.

Many aspects of the South's culture remain deeply rooted in the American Civil
War.

In the last few decades,[_[vague](/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness
"Wikipedia:Vagueness")_] the Southern US has been attracting domestic and
international migrants, and the American
South[_[vague](/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness "Wikipedia:Vagueness")_] is among the
fastest-growing[_[vague](/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness "Wikipedia:Vagueness")_]
areas in the United States.

## New
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eastern_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: New England")]

Main article: [New England](/wiki/New_England "New England")

New England is a region of the United States located in the northeastern
corner of the country, bounded by the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean
"Atlantic Ocean"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and the state of [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), consisting of the modern
states of [Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine"), [New Hampshire](/wiki/New_Hampshire
"New Hampshire"), [Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont"),
[Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts"), [Rhode
Island](/wiki/Rhode_Island "Rhode Island"), and
[Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut").

In one of the earliest English settlements in the [New World](/wiki/New_World
"New World"), English [Pilgrims](/wiki/Pilgrims "Pilgrims") from Europe first
settled in New England in 1620, in the colony of
[Plymouth](/wiki/Plymouth_Colony "Plymouth Colony"). In the late 18th century,
the New England colonies would be among the first North American British
colonies to demonstrate ambitions of independence from the [British
Crown](/wiki/British_Crown "British Crown"), although they would later
threaten secession over the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812")
between the United States and Britain.

New England produced the first examples of American literature and philosophy
and was home to the beginnings of free public education. In the 19th century,
it played a prominent role in the movement to abolish [slavery in the United
States](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States"). It
was the first region of the United States to be transformed by the [Industrial
Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution").

Historically an area in which parts were strongly
[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)"), it is now a region with one of the highest levels of
support for the [Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"Democratic Party \(United States\)") in the United States, with the majority
of voters in every state voting for the Democrats in the
[1992](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1992 "United States
presidential election, 1992"),
[1996](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1996 "United States
presidential election, 1996"),
[2004](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2004 "United States
presidential election, 2004"),
[2008](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008 "United States
presidential election, 2008"),
[2012](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2012 "United States
presidential election, 2012") and
[2016](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United States
presidential election, 2016") Presidential elections, and every state but New
Hampshire voting for [Al Gore](/wiki/Al_Gore "Al Gore") in 2000.

## The
Midwest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eastern_United_States&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: The Midwest")]

Main article: [Midwestern United States](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States
"Midwestern United States")

The Midwestern United States (in the U.S. generally referred to as the
Midwest) is one of the four geographic regions within the United States that
are recognized by the United States Census Bureau.

Seven states in the central and inland northeastern US, traditionally
considered to be part of the Midwest, can also be classified as being part of
the Eastern United States: [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"),
[Indiana](/wiki/Indiana "Indiana"), [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa "Iowa"),
[Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan"), [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota
"Minnesota"), [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio"), and [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin
"Wisconsin"). A 2006 Census Bureau estimate put the population at 66,217,736.
The United States Census Bureau divides this region into the East North
Central States (essentially the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes")
States) and the West North Central States.

[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago") is the largest city in the region, followed
by [Indianapolis](/wiki/Indianapolis "Indianapolis") and
[Columbus](/wiki/Columbus,_Ohio "Columbus, Ohio"). Chicago has the largest
metropolitan statistical area, followed by Detroit, and [Minneapolis – Saint
Paul](/wiki/Minneapolis_%E2%80%93_Saint_Paul "Minneapolis – Saint Paul").
[Sault Ste. Marie](/wiki/Sault_Ste._Marie,_Michigan "Sault Ste. Marie,
Michigan"), Michigan is the oldest city in the region, having been founded by
[French](/wiki/French_people "French people") [missionaries](/wiki/Missionary
"Missionary") and explorers in 1668.

The term Midwest has been in common use for over 100 years. Another term
sometimes applied to the same general region is "the heartland". Other
designations for the region have fallen into disuse, such as the "Northwest"
or "Old Northwest" (from "Northwest Territory") and "Mid-America". Since the
book _[Middletown](/wiki/Middletown_studies "Middletown studies")_ appeared in
1929, [sociologists](/wiki/Sociologists "Sociologists") have often used
Midwestern cities (and the Midwest generally) as "typical" of the entire
nation. The region has a higher [employment-to-population
ratio](/wiki/Employment-to-population_ratio "Employment-to-population ratio")
(the percentage of employed people at least 16 years old) than the Northeast,
the West, the South, or the Sun Belt states.

Four of the states associated with the Midwestern United States
([Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"), [Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska"),
[North Dakota](/wiki/North_Dakota "North Dakota"), and [South
Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota "South Dakota")) are also traditionally referred to
as belonging in part to the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains")
region.
